comments.commentBody:
Now, let's see Josh Satin blossom like a rose at first base.

It was nice knowing you, Ike.
From Satin anyway...

He should have stayed out of the weight room. which adds more stress on the obliques.  With his contract up and subject to negotiation I doubt he will be back next season.  There's too much competition from Duda and Satin.

Bohemienne, I wonder if these pampered misses are the ones who are complaining of debt? If they are, there is definitely something wrong with both their parents values, their own shallow priorities, and a society that says to them that everyone has to live like a king, as Suzanna points out.

I would think that those mired in debt are not the products of upper middle class parents who provide an open ended charge account, but rather the children of less wealthy parents who cannot afford to pay for tuition, and may not be able to afford to send their kid 'away to college' at all.

It was fun living as a poor student. We always had enough to eat, had enough for enough, but not endless, beer, and we learned a lot about money management and how to score the cheap or free stuff. My only regret was on the fashion front, and not even the advent of free wheeling hippie regalia set that to rest - it cost money too.

That frugality persisted all our lives. We still have the same living room furniture we bought 35 years ago. I am thinking of having it recovered. We didn't replace it every few years, and didn't give a thought to granite counters. We have lived very well, and think we have enough retirement savings.

It is all marketing, almost everything we are exposed to says - spend money.

Not a good thing, and never was.

The identity group du jour, in your infelicitous phrase, is half the human race, not a small minority. I take it that you do not think that advancing women in the professions or engaging in discussions that involve issues of particular interest to women are important because they are not problems that "all people" face. De facto, therefore, you think that only the employment of men and the concerns of men need to be addressed.

So, we can talk about sexism when we've solved problems that everyone faces? I think you mentioned pollution, economic disparities, and trade pacts.

Gee, thanks! Hey ladies, only once we've solved the real problems, then maybe we can get to that pesky little sexism thing. Because frankly, our problems with sexism are a)unimportant because they affect only women and b) totally unrelated to things like the world economy, environmental concerns, and other big important stuff like that.

Wow. I mean, what a bizarre response. Women make up more than 50% of the population, so technically, we are the majority. That means we are the group most affected by the problems you mention, and we have biggest stake in solving them. But don't worry, I'm sure someday men will get their turn as the identity group du jour,
"The identity group du jour"? Only those who have the privilege of having *their* identities be the default in society whine about "identity poiltics."

Please don't suggest affirmative action for philosophy. Linking the core missions of disciplines to the policies of  the human resources department has already ruined the humanities by narrowing the discourse, and deflecting attention from other problems like pollution and ecology,  economic disparities, trade pacts that hurt  workers and the death of the commons. These are problems that all people face, not just the identity group du jour.
Pendant, there was no intent to insult religious people, just to ask them to butt out of other people's business.
I loved this.  Well written.  As a hospice nurse, I hear this often.

Earl W.,
I think that they might be suggesting that since the transplant is worth more to someone with a greater income, they should pay more for it.

Not unlike how contractors giving estimates for an addition, say will quote a cost that is somewhat related to the value of the house and neighborhood they are going to work on (so I hear).

As a rationale for justifying why wealthy people should be paying more for healthcare, I think it makes sense, at least if one thinks like an economist, but alas, economic theory also dictates that if physicians are paid more to cure wealthy people, they will prefer to do so. Ultimately, you get what you pay for, no?

That is why Prof. Reinhardt proposes an all payer system.

Lots and lots and lots of children ride the bus every day.  In rural and small-town America, it's often the only way to get to school.  Millions of kids even ride ride on the first day.  I suppose I must believe that you truly didn't know this, but I find it bizarre that  you would doubt the veracity of the entire post because of it.  And then by extension all other posts on this blog!

I agree! I especially love the close-up photo of Rebecca Johnson and Britney Nichols (slide 1 in the series), which captures their quiet joy and tenderness. In fact, that photo drew me in to read the article. Well done.

Congratulations to NYT's photographer Mark Holm for the artistic, creative and sensitive coverage in New Mexico.

The shot of Patricia Catlett and Karen Schmiege, the first same-sex couple in Bernalillo County to get a marriage license, was brilliant, as the reflection of the media plus the couple's intensity looking at the computer screen, is so touching!

Please nominate Mark for a Pulitzer.

Adam died in his soul immediately upon the fall

Ezekiel 18:4 The soul that sinneth it shall die

Until a man becomes born again , he remains "dead in trespasses and sins" Ephesians 2:1

1Timothy 5:6
But she that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth.

(etc.) God did not lie to Adam when He prophesied to him of his forthcoming transgression - In the day you eat thereof you shall surely die

Turbot

Did you read the article? The first sentence of the fourth paragraph clearly states:

"That has left New Mexico as the only state in the country that has no statute or constitutional amendment explicitly barring same-sex couples from marrying, but also no law saying they can."
"Thousands of years of human civilization" is more about war and peace,  slavery and freedom, justice and injustice. It's certainly no defense of "marriage".
Given this AG's six-year long record of punting or ignoring a host of issues important to New Mexico, yes, it probably is an appropriate word.

Ed,

Approximately one-third of Americans live in jurisdictions that allow gay marriage, so marriage is not just between a man and a woman.

You can say it all you want, but it is no longer true. Furthermore, in the USA, gay marriage will never, ever again be the law of the land.

Your point-of-view is passé. Get over it.

Mr. Dobbs, some of us hope that these clerks will have robust political careers.  Few remember that our beloved Mayor David Dinkins spent time as New York County (Manhattan) Clerk.  This article reminded me.  I thank them and wish them well.
Excuse me, it was President Bush (wasn't he a Republican) who repeatedly used "signing statements" in an attempt to modify/change the meaning of laws passed by Congress.
Too late at night.  It was City Clerk.  Point doesn't change.

The task is still not trivial just for U.S. workers, though.

Are we going to count part-time workers or only full-time? Lots of benefits - health insurance, for example - are not valued in anything reported to the IRS (That specific example may be changing under the Healthcare Act, but the general point stands). Even if it's only full-time workers, how do we deal with people who worked somewhere less than a full-year? Pro rate their salaries? Count them all, or combine people who replaced others?

These aren't as simple as they seem, when you are dealing with tens of thousands of employees.
We live in an age of victimology.  If less than half of the academic philosophers are women then the only explanation is discrimination!

The article was only mildly interesting. The author, while hinting at possible causes, does not clearly offer her opinion as to why there are so few female philosophers in academia.

I have one simple question: Is the paucity of female philosophers soley a function of societal deprivations and prejudeces, or are there other areas and possibilities worth exploring?
what a deal for Vodafone! and as for Verizon their entire board of directors should be thrown in jail for life!
big companies are putting a real beating o these trash funds this year!
This is an opportunity for Vodafone to buy right back into the U.S. market and make its brand truly global, yes?
No, What does it feel like?

McKinsey-ites are idiots on steroids.  They are famous for being famous---sort of like Soupy Sales.  They'll borrow your watch to tell you the time.  Like Goldman Sachs or Citibank alums, they comprise an entrenched elite working against the interests of the greater society to maximize their ego, their influence and their wealth.

I wonder if this deal has anything todo with all the phone data the government is collecting from Verizon. If Vodafone owns 45% of Verizon wouldn't Vodafone a foreign country have access to the same data?
